thread.title: H.S. girls cross-country: Ridgewood’s plan leads to victory - Sports
thread.title_full: H.S. girls cross-country: Ridgewood’s plan leads to victory - Sports - NorthJersey.com

author: DAVE MEISEL
title: H.S. girls cross-country: Ridgewood’s plan leads to victory - Sports
text:
WOODLAND PARK – Samantha Halvorsen and Olympia Martin took second and third place to vault the Ridgewood girls to the Big North Freedom Division cross-country championship Thursday.
Ridgewood coach Steve Opremcak praised his team’s ability to stick to a plan as it scored 35 points at Garret Mountain Reservation to top Northern Highlands’ 43 points.
“Obviously we want all seven girls running a perfect race, but that’s hard to have that, so we worked together in two packs,” Opremcak said. “I’m a numbers guy, and I always look at the splits, so we always know what we want to do.”
Halvorsen (19:16) and Martin (19:18) were joined by Hannah Fishbein (ninth, 20:41), Cassie Keyes (20:53, 10th), Leah Rosenfield (11th, 21:00), Sophia Sheehy (13th, 21:10) and Meghan Adams (14th, 21:19).
“We are integrating new girls into the team, as really four of them are new to running together due to missing last season or being new to the team, but they’re working hard together,” Opremcak said. “If we run to our ability, we should qualify for [the Bergen Meet of Champions].”
Indian Hills’ Julia Guerra raced to an 18:47 to capture the individual Freedom Division girls title.
NV/Old Tappan had little experience at Garret Mountain this season due to scheduling changes, but managed to rout the National Division competition, scoring 22 points to second-place Pascack Valley’s 58. But the Indians’ Ashley Evans (19:43) won the title.
Courtney Brunet (20:21), Kristen Travers (20:57), Nicole Brougher (21:08) and Mary Scrivanich (21:16) finished second through fifth to lead the Golden Knights.
“We knew we needed separation in the middle mile, and going around the lake, places two through six were pretty tight,” coach Jeff Clark said. “But we did what we needed to do and ran well collectively. [Winner Ashley] Evans of Passaic Valley was a standout performer of this race, though.”
 
 
Tenafly used its experience at Garret Mountain to its advantage as it raced to the boys National Division championship.
Coach Dave Burns saw last week’s meet with NV/Old Tappan and Bergenfield as a tuneup for the league meet, which Tenafly won by just one point over second-place NV/Demarest, 33 to 34.
Despite a bloody nose before the race, Max Zavidow was able to lead Tenafly, finishing second in 16:37.
“I told Max, ‘If you don’t feel good enough, get second,’ and it was great that he was able to do that because our goal was the team title,” Burns said.
Seniors Michael Silverman (17:24), Frank Maloney (17:25) and Ed Salaski (17:31) were the next three up for Tenafly, finishing sixth, seventh and eighth respectively.
James Weissenborn of NV/Old Tappan won the National Division race in 16:19.
Indian Hills edged Ridgewood in the boys’ Freedom Division Championship, 29 to 34.
The Braves’ confident bunch was led by Matt Cohane, who raced to a second-place finish (16:25). Teammate Steven Fiumefreddo (16:31) took third. Chris Corcoran (16:44), Derek Barney (16:49), Thomas Holster (16:53) and Chris Leymeister (17:04) finished seventh through 10th for Indian Hills.
Billy Byrne of Ridgewood edged Cohane (16:24) to win the race.
